title: Disenchanter

A **disenchanter**, R, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is the only other member of the [rust monster or disenchanter](/wiki/Rust_monster_or_disenchanter "Rust monster or disenchanter") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class").

Disenchanters are [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal") that can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). They possess a single claw attack and a passive attack: both can decrease the positive [enchantments](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") (or charges if applicable) of its target's equipment, with the claw weakening worn [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor") and the other weakening [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") and other items that strike the disenchanter. [Artifacts](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") have a 9⁄10 chance of resisting in both cases.

Eating a disenchanter [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") will remove a random [intrinsic](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic"), as with the [intrinsic-stealing](/wiki/Intrinsic-stealing "Intrinsic-stealing") attack used by a [gremlin](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Message](#Message)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [6.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.4 xNetHack](#xNetHack)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Randomly generated disenchanters are always hostile. Disenchanters are only randomly generated in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), though they are a valid form for normal polymorph, and they can also be created by the [summon nasties](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").

The random R generated in the central room of the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") at level creation has a chance of being a disenchanter.

## Strategy

Disenchanters are a nightmare to face in close combat due to their very good [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of -10. The disenchanting claw attack is subject to [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation"): MC3 via a [cloak of protection](/wiki/Cloak_of_protection "Cloak of protection") or other means will reduce the probability of your armor losing enchantment, but does not affect the [passive](/wiki/Passive "Passive") disenchanting attack. Thankfully, disenchanters have [0 MR](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"), leaving them completely vulnerable to magical effects such as [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph"), [cancellation](/wiki/Cancellation "Cancellation"), and [sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep"), and they can be easily warded off using instruments such as a [tooled horn](/wiki/Tooled_horn "Tooled horn") or [leather drum](/wiki/Leather_drum "Leather drum") to scare them. [Attack spells](/wiki/Attack_spell "Attack spell") and [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") can keep them at bay with far less risk to your armor, though their AC will make landing shots a major problem.

The "simplest" method of killing a disenchanter is to solely use unenchanted options, such as weapon-tools like [pick-axes](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe") or [unicorn horns](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn"), or else secondary starting weapons that went mostly unused. If you can immobilize a disenchanter, or else armor enchantment is not a pressing issue for you, you can also remove your [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves") to preserve their enchantment and bash it to death with your bare hands - [Monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk") aiming to [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") one to death will also want to mind the enchantment of their [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots"). Similarly, strong pets that do not rely on weapons or else are wielding unenchanted ones will have no trouble against them.

Disenchanters are often a common target for single-species [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"), as rust monsters are not much of a threat once the player reaches Gehennom. However, they can also be useful to roles who cannot reliably cast [drain life](/wiki/Drain_life "Drain life"): a wielded weapon or piece of armor can have its enchantment selectively reduced by wielding the item and hitting the disenchanter with it, so that it can be re-enchanted to a higher level.

## History

The disenchanter first appears in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

## Origin

The disenchanter is a monster that originates in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, making its debut in the 1st edition *Fiend Folio* and issue #6 of *White Dwarf*. It is often described as a blue-furred quadrupedal creature with an elephant-like trunk and a camel-esque body and "hump". Disenchanters are considered even more infamous in tabletop settings, not solely for their magic-eating abilities, but also for their somewhat goofy-looking designs.

## Message

- Your \<item> seems less effective.

  A weapon or piece of armor was subjected to disenchantment.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), disenchanter corpses and tins are safe to eat. Additionally, they are no longer the only monster that can disenchant weapons and armor with the addition of the [steel golem](/wiki/Steel_golem "Steel golem"), which has also a passive disenchanting attack.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), eating a disenchanter corpse or tin only has a 1⁄2 chance of removing a random intrinsic. If you are [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating"), it has a 1⁄5 of ending hallucination immediately.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), two disenchanters appear within one of the rooms in [Demogorgon](/wiki/Demogorgon "Demogorgon")'s lair if his dwelling appears as [the third Abyss level](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine_Flats#Demogorgon.27s_palace "User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine Flats").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), eating a disenchanter corpse or tin while hallucinating cures that status property without targeting any other intrinsic - this also breaks perma-hallucination [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct").

## Encyclopedia entry

Ask not, what your magic can do to it. Ask what it can do to your magic.

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

R disenchanter

R disenchanter
Difficulty 14
Attacks

Claw 4d4 disenchant, passive disenchant

Base level 12
Base experience 301
Speed 12
Base AC −10
Base MR 0
Alignment −3 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 750
Nutritional value 200
Size Large
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A disenchanter:

  • is an animal.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • appears only in Gehennom.
Reference monst.c#line1737

A disenchanter, R, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is the only other member of the rust monster or disenchanter monster class.

Disenchanters are carnivorous animals that can be seen via infravision. They possess a single claw attack and a passive attack: both can decrease the positive enchantments (or charges if applicable) of its target's equipment, with the claw weakening worn armor and the other weakening weapons and other items that strike the disenchanter. Artifacts have a 9⁄10 chance of resisting in both cases.

Eating a disenchanter corpse or tin will remove a random intrinsic, as with the intrinsic-stealing attack used by a gremlin.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Message
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 UnNetHack
    • 6.3 dNetHack
    • 6.4 xNetHack
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Randomly generated disenchanters are always hostile. Disenchanters are only randomly generated in Gehennom, though they are a valid form for normal polymorph, and they can also be created by the summon nasties monster spell.

The random R generated in the central room of the Castle at level creation has a chance of being a disenchanter.

Strategy

Disenchanters are a nightmare to face in close combat due to their very good AC of -10. The disenchanting claw attack is subject to magic cancellation: MC3 via a cloak of protection or other means will reduce the probability of your armor losing enchantment, but does not affect the passive disenchanting attack. Thankfully, disenchanters have 0 MR, leaving them completely vulnerable to magical effects such as polymorph, cancellation, and sleep, and they can be easily warded off using instruments such as a tooled horn or leather drum to scare them. Attack spells and wands can keep them at bay with far less risk to your armor, though their AC will make landing shots a major problem.

The "simplest" method of killing a disenchanter is to solely use unenchanted options, such as weapon-tools like pick-axes or unicorn horns, or else secondary starting weapons that went mostly unused. If you can immobilize a disenchanter, or else armor enchantment is not a pressing issue for you, you can also remove your gloves to preserve their enchantment and bash it to death with your bare hands - Monks aiming to kick one to death will also want to mind the enchantment of their boots. Similarly, strong pets that do not rely on weapons or else are wielding unenchanted ones will have no trouble against them.

Disenchanters are often a common target for single-species genocide, as rust monsters are not much of a threat once the player reaches Gehennom. However, they can also be useful to roles who cannot reliably cast drain life: a wielded weapon or piece of armor can have its enchantment selectively reduced by wielding the item and hitting the disenchanter with it, so that it can be re-enchanted to a higher level.

History

The disenchanter first appears in NetHack 3.3.0.

Origin

The disenchanter is a monster that originates in Dungeons & Dragons, making its debut in the 1st edition Fiend Folio and issue #6 of White Dwarf. It is often described as a blue-furred quadrupedal creature with an elephant-like trunk and a camel-esque body and "hump". Disenchanters are considered even more infamous in tabletop settings, not solely for their magic-eating abilities, but also for their somewhat goofy-looking designs.

Message

Your <item> seems less effective.
A weapon or piece of armor was subjected to disenchantment.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, disenchanter corpses and tins are safe to eat. Additionally, they are no longer the only monster that can disenchant weapons and armor with the addition of the steel golem, which has also a passive disenchanting attack.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, eating a disenchanter corpse or tin only has a 1⁄2 chance of removing a random intrinsic. If you are hallucinating, it has a 1⁄5 of ending hallucination immediately.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, two disenchanters appear within one of the rooms in Demogorgon's lair if his dwelling appears as the third Abyss level.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, eating a disenchanter corpse or tin while hallucinating cures that status property without targeting any other intrinsic - this also breaks perma-hallucination conduct.

Encyclopedia entry

Ask not, what your magic can do to it. Ask what it can do to your magic.

A '''disenchanter''', {{monsym|disenchanter}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is the only other member of the [[rust monster or disenchanter]] [[monster class]].

Disenchanters are [[carnivorous]] [[animal]]s that can be seen via [[infravision]]. They possess a single claw attack and a passive attack: both can decrease the positive [[enchantment]]s (or charges if applicable) of its target's equipment, with the claw weakening worn [[armor]] and the other weakening [[weapon]]s and other items that strike the disenchanter. [[Artifact]]s have a {{frac|9|10}} chance of resisting in both cases.

Eating a disenchanter [[corpse]] or [[tin]] will remove a random [[intrinsic]], as with the [[intrinsic-stealing]] attack used by a [[gremlin]].

==Generation==
Randomly generated disenchanters are always hostile. Disenchanters are only randomly generated in [[Gehennom]], though they are a valid form for normal polymorph, and they can also be created by the [[summon nasties]] [[monster spell]].

The random {{white|R}} generated in the central room of the [[Castle]] at level creation has a chance of being a disenchanter.

==Strategy==
Disenchanters are a nightmare to face in close combat due to their very good [[AC]] of -10. The disenchanting claw attack is subject to [[magic cancellation]]: MC3 via a [[cloak of protection]] or other means will reduce the probability of your armor losing enchantment, but does not affect the [[passive]] disenchanting attack. Thankfully, disenchanters have [[Magic resistance (monster)|0 MR]], leaving them completely vulnerable to magical effects such as [[polymorph]], [[cancellation]], and [[sleep]], and they can be easily warded off using instruments such as a [[tooled horn]] or [[leather drum]] to scare them. [[Attack spell]]s and [[wand]]s can keep them at bay with far less risk to your armor, though their AC will make landing shots a major problem.

The "simplest" method of killing a disenchanter is to solely use unenchanted options, such as weapon-tools like [[pick-axe]]s or [[unicorn horn]]s, or else secondary starting weapons that went mostly unused. If you can immobilize a disenchanter, or else armor enchantment is not a pressing issue for you, you can also remove your [[gloves]] to preserve their enchantment and bash it to death with your bare hands - [[Monk]]s aiming to [[kick]] one to death will also want to mind the enchantment of their [[boots]]. Similarly, strong pets that do not rely on weapons or else are wielding unenchanted ones will have no trouble against them.

Disenchanters are often a common target for single-species [[genocide]], as rust monsters are not much of a threat once the player reaches Gehennom. However, they can also be useful to roles who cannot reliably cast [[drain life]]: a wielded weapon or piece of armor can have its enchantment selectively reduced by wielding the item and hitting the disenchanter with it, so that it can be re-enchanted to a higher level.

==History==
The disenchanter first appears in [[NetHack 3.3.0]].

==Origin==
The disenchanter is a monster that originates in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', making its debut in the 1st edition ''Fiend Folio'' and issue  #6 of ''White Dwarf''. It is often described as a blue-furred quadrupedal creature with an elephant-like trunk and a camel-esque body and "hump". Disenchanters are considered even more infamous in tabletop settings, not solely for their magic-eating abilities, but also for their somewhat goofy-looking designs.

==Message==
{{message|Your <item> seems less effective.|A weapon or piece of armor was subjected to disenchantment.}}

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], disenchanter corpses and tins are safe to eat. Additionally, they are no longer the only monster that can disenchant weapons and armor with the addition of the [[steel golem]], which has also a passive disenchanting attack.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], eating a disenchanter corpse or tin only has a {{frac|2}} chance of removing a random intrinsic. If you are [[hallucinating]], it has a {{frac|5}} of ending hallucination immediately.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], two disenchanters appear within one of the rooms in [[Demogorgon]]'s lair if his dwelling appears as [[User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine Flats#Demogorgon's palace|the third Abyss level]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], eating a disenchanter corpse or tin while hallucinating cures that status property without targeting any other intrinsic - this also breaks perma-hallucination [[conduct]].

==Encyclopedia entry==
